Introduction

In an effort to reduce the risks associated with an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia, an extremely hazardous chemical, and to comply with the requirements set fourth in the Clean Air Act (CAA) amendmensts 112(r), Marsh Supermarket, LLC ("Marsh") has completed the following Risk Management Plan for its Perishable Products Warehouse facility at the above referenced address ("Facility"). Marsh is committed to providing a safe and healthy work place for all of its employees at the Facility. This commitment is evidenced by Marsh's safety audit program and safety training requirements for employees responsible for handling the ammonia at the Facility.                                      

In addition, Marsh recognizes the importance of being a "good neighbor"  to the community in the vicinity of the Facility, particularly in regard to the safe handling and storage of ammonia at the Facility. Accordingly, Marsh has dedicated and intends to dedicate the necessary resources to reduce the risks associated with an accidental release of ammonia at the Facility through preparation, planning and implementation of a Process Safety Management ("PSM") program for the Facility. The specifics of the PSM program have been outlined in the following sections.

The accident release prevention and emergency response policies at the facility.

Safety in the workplace, including the safe handling and storage of ammonia at the Facility, continues to be one of Marsh's highest priorities. Marsh is not only committed to complying with federal, state and local regulations regarding ammonia at the Facility, but also to going beyond the legal requirements with its best management practices, which includes matters such as internal auditing of safety and health matters, evaluating alternatives to reducing the amount of ammonia necessary for the Facility, and training additional employees beyond regulatory requirements. Further, Marsh is committed to implementing the PSM program

as described thoughout this summary.

Facility and the regulated substances handled.

The Facility is approximately 193,000 square feet in area, and sits on approximately 12.21 acres of land in Yorktown, Indiana, located in southwestern Delaware County, Indiana. The Facility is similar to a typical warehouse used to store perishable food products prior to their distribution and sale to the consumer. Due to the perishable nature of the food products stored in the Facility (i.e.dairy products, meats, fruits, vegetables, etc.), the interior temperatures of the Facility are controlled with a refrigeration system. This refrigeration system uses liquid anhydrous ammonia to keep portions of the Facility between 50 F and 28F on a continual basis. Typically, less than 10,000 pounds or 1,946 gallons of anhydrous ammonia are maintained at the site of the Facility.

Anhydrous ammonia is considered to be extremely hazardous under certain conditions. Anhydrous ammonia is a gas at atmospheric temperature and pressure. In its gas form, ammonia is colorless, but has an intensely irritating odor and may cause eye, nose and throat irritation and breathing difficulties. If concentrations of the gas are sufficiently high, inhalation can cause respiratory tract irritation and/or death. Ammonia has a vapor density of 0.6 compared to air (1.0); consequently, the gas dissipates into the atmosphere. Although the gas will dissipate into the atmosphere, it is recommended to stay up-wind and out of low lying areas should a release of ammonia occur.

Worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s)

A worst-case and alternative release scenario were calculated using RMP*Comp to determine endpoints for each scenario. The endpoints were as follows:
          Worst-case Release Scenario = 0.4 miles
         Alternative Release Scenario = 0.2 miles
The worst-case release scenario considered a release of the full 10,000 pounds to the atmosphere over a ten (10) minute duration. T

he distance of 0.4 miles calculated above constitutes an endpoint. An endpoint is considered the furthest extent of impact given the variables in the scenario. In this case, offsite public receptors (e.g., residences) would be affected by toxic concetrations from an accidental release.

It is unlikely that a worst-case release scenario would occur due to the systems and controls utilized in connection with the Facility, such as, the computer systems which continuously monitors the refrigeration system and promptly alerts the operator of any malfunctions, and 24 hour guard service at the Facility.

The alternative release scenario considered a release of 1,000 pounds to the atmosphere over a 24 hour duration. As described above, a distance of 0.2 miles was calculated as the endpoint for this scenario. In this case, offsite public receptors could be affected by toxic concentrations from an accidental release of ammonia from the Facility.

This scenario was used as the alternative release scenario because it is similar to a release at the Facility in 1997. The release was considered as a "typical" release scenario for the facility.

General accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps.

Marsh is in the process (June and July of 1999) of thoroughly reviewing all of its policies and procedures concerning the Facility's refrigeration system. Specifically, the standard operating procedures concerning the operation, maintenance and handling of anhydrous ammonia will be evaluated. It is anticipated that the final review and revisions to the PSM program will be in place by August 1, 1999.

In addition, training for all operators of the refrigeration system at the Facility will be evaluated to ensure its compliance with all applicable regulatory requirements and manufacturers' specifications, as well as Marsh's best management practices.

The five-year accident history

In the past five years, the Facility has not experienced any accidents withi

n the definition set forth in Chapter 3.1 of EPA's Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration, EPA 550-B-98-014, November 1998.

The emergency response program.

Marsh maintains an Emergency Action Plan for the Facility. The purpose of the plan is to protect employees from serious injury, property loss or the loss of life in the event of a major disaster. The Emergency Action Plan outlines responsibilities and actions to be taken in an emergency situaiton. It descriges the in-house warning system, ammonia alarm system, evacuation procedures and emergency shutdown procedures. It also outlines employee responsibilities and emergency contact numbers.

Planned changes to improve safety.

The review of the PSM should be completed by August 1, 1999. It is believed that the review may result in improvements to operation and maintenance of the refrigeration system of the Facility, such as enhancements to its computer monitoring system and additional monitoring devices, as well as the training of additional employees with responsibility for the operation and maintenance fo the refrigeration system at the Facility.
